<h2>ill-bred[sound:ill-bred.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">没有教养的，没有礼貌的：</font>badly brought up or showing bad upbringing: impolite</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Only an ill-bred, conceited person would demand that everyone cater to their whims. 只有一个没有教养、狂妄自大的人才会要求所有人都去迎合他的想法。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]discourteous, disrespectful, impertinent, impolite, inconsiderate, rude, uncivil, ungracious, unmannerly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]civil, considerate, courteous, genteel, gracious, mannerly, polite, urbane, well-bred 有礼貌的，得体的</div>
<h2>menial[sound:menial.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">仆人，奴仆：</font>a servant, especially a domestic servant</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Immigrants to that country faced fierce prejudice and could expect to find work only as menials.  前往那个国家的移民遭到了严重的歧视，他们也许只能找到像仆人一类的工作。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]domestic, retainer, steward</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]lord, master, mistress 主人</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">卑贱的，低下的：</font>showing,  expressing,  or  offered  in  a  spirit  of  humility  or  unseemlysubmissiveness</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]low-paid menial jobs such as cleaning the street 一些低收入的卑贱工作，比如扫大街</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]base, humble, lowly, servile, slavish, subservient</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]arrogant, haughty, imperious, lordly, supercilious, superior 自大的，狂妄的</div>
<h2>peculiarity[sound:peculiarity.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">特征，特点：</font>a distinguishing characteristic</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]It is a peculiarity of the house that there is no front door. 没有大门是这座房子的一个特色。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]attribute, character, criterion, diagnostic, differentia, feature, fingerprint, hallmark, mark, note, particularity, quality, specific, trait</div>
<h2>premeditate[sound:premeditate.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">预谋：</font>to think about and revolve in the mind beforehand</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]carefully premeditating each step of his plan of campaign 仔细地计划着竞选计划中的每一个步骤</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]forethink, precogitate, predetermine</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]disregard, ignore, overlook, slight 忽略</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]premeditated adj. 有预谋的</div>
<h2>wanting[sound:wanting.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">未出现的，缺少的：</font>not present or in evidence</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Grass is almost entirely wanting in that arid wasteland.  那片荒漠几乎没有长一丝青草。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]absent, lacking, missing, nonexistent</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]existent, present 存在的，出现的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">未达到要求的：</font>not being up to standards or expectations</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He examined her work and found it wanting. 他检查了她的作业，发现不合要求。‖We tried her cookingand found it to be very wanting. 我们试了试她的厨艺，结果发现很不尽人意。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]deficient, dissatisfactory, ill, inferior, lousy, paltry, poor, unacceptable, unsatisfactory, wretched</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]acceptable, adequate, passable, tolerable 可接受的；satisfactory 令人满意的</div>
<h2>idiosyncrasy[sound:idiosyncrasy.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">独特而奇怪的习惯：</font>an odd or peculiar habit</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]His only idiosyncrasy is his inveterate wearing of sneakers, even with business suits. 他唯一的怪癖就是无时无刻都穿着运动鞋——哪怕身上是西装革履。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]crotchet, eccentricity, individualism, mannerism, oddity, peculiarity, quirk, singularity, trick, twist</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]conformity, sameness 合乎（礼节等），千篇一律</div>
<h2>august[sound:august.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">威严的，庄重的：</font>having or showing a formal and serious or reserved manner</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Unsurprisingly, the head of the bank is an august white-haired gentleman. 不出所料的，银行的总裁是一名白发苍苍的、令人顿生敬意的绅士。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]distinguished, imposing, portly, solemn, staid, stately</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]flighty, frivolous, giddy, goofy, silly, undignified 轻浮的，不庄重的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">盛大的，令人印象深刻的：</font>large and impressive in size, grandeur, extent, or conception</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]an august golden anniversary celebration for the company 盛大的周年庆祝会</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]baronial, epic, grandiose, imperial, magnificent, majestic, massive, monumental, noble, regal, splendid</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]common, humble, mediocre, ordinary, unimposing, unimpressive 普通的，一般的</div>
<h2>coy[sound:coy.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">故作羞涩的：</font>affectedly and usually flirtatiously shy or modest</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Not wanting him to know that she was interested in him, she acted very coy at the dance. 她在舞会上故意装得很娇羞的样子，不想让他知道她喜欢他。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]coquettish, demure, kittenish</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">不愿与人交往的，内向的：</font>tending to avoid people and social situations</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She was modest without being coy. 她很低调，但又不至于内向。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]backward, bashful, diffident, introverted, modest, recessive, retiring, sheepish, shy, withdrawn</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]extroverted, immodest, outgoing 外向的</div>
<h2>demote[sound:demote.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">降职，降级：</font>to reduce to a lower grade or rank</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The court-martial’s decision was to demote the officer responsible for the failed mission. 军事法庭决定对为此次失败任务负责的军官进行降职处理。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]break, bust, degrade, disrate, downgrade, reduce</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]advance, elevate, promote, raise 提升，晋升</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]demotion n. 降职</div>
<h2>staunch[sound:staunch.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">忠诚的，坚定的：</font>steadfast in loyalty or principle</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a staunch believer in the democratic system 民主制度的坚定拥护者‖No matter what happens I will beyour staunchest supporters. 不论发生什么，我都会是你最忠诚的支持者。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]constant, dedicated, devoted, devout, faithful, fast, loyal, pious, steadfast, steady, true, true-blue</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]disloyal, inconstant, perfidious, recreant, traitorous, treacherous  不忠诚的；fickle 善变的</div>
<h2>atrophy[sound:atrophy.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vi. <font color="#aa00ff">萎缩，衰退：</font>to waste away; wither or deteriorate</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The years following the closing of the last textile mill, the town atrophied.  随着最后一家纺织厂的倒闭，整个城镇开始衰退。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]crumble, decay, decline, degenerate, descend, devolve, ebb, regress, retrograde, rot, sink, worsen</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]ameliorate, improve, meliorate 改善，提升</div>
<h2>idle[sound:idle.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">闲置的，未使用的：</font>not turned to normal or appropriate use</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The car was idle for two weeks while they went on vacation. 因为他们出去旅行了，他们的车闲置了两周。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]dead, dormant, fallow, free, inert, inoperative, latent, unused, vacant</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]active, alive, employed, functioning, operative, running, working  使用中的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">懒散的：</font>shiftless, lazy</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]an idle employee who always seems to be either on break or at lunch 这个懒散的员工似乎不是在休息就是在吃饭</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]indolent, lazy, shiftless, slothful</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]diligent, industrious 勤奋的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】vi. <font color="#aa00ff">懒散度日，无所事事：</font>to pass (time) without working or while avoiding work</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]idle the afternoon away 打发下午的时光</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]dally, dillydally, drone, laze, loaf, loll, lounge</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]drudge, grind, hustle, labor, moil, plod, slave, sweat, toil, travail, work  （辛苦地）干活，工作</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]idlly adv. 懒散地</div>
<h2>splutter[sound:splutter.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vi. <font color="#aa00ff">急切而不清楚地说：</font>to speak hastily and incoherently, as when confused or angry</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]They begin to splutter and move restlessly about if they feel time is slipping away without some return.当他们感到时间在悄悄流逝却一无所得时，他们便开始激动地说话，不安地走动。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]babble, drivel, gabble, gibber, jabber, sputter, stammer, stutter</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]articulate, enunciate, pronounce 清楚地说</div>
<h2>vouchsafe[sound:vouchsafe.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">允诺，给予：</font>to grant or furnish often in a gracious or condescending manner</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]refused to vouchsafe an explanation  拒绝给出任何解释</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accord, award, grant, vest</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]withhold 保留，不给予；recant, retract, withdraw 撤回，收回</div>
<h2>deadlock[sound:deadlock.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">僵局：</font>a state of inaction or neutralization  resulting from the opposition of equally powerfuluncompromising persons or factions</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The deadlock was broken with a key compromise.  一个关键性的妥协打破了僵局。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]gridlock, halt, impasse, logjam, stalemate, standoff, standstill</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使陷入僵局，使停顿：</font>to bring or come to a deadlock</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]expedite 加速进程</div>
<h2>groggy[sound:groggy.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">虚弱的，（走路）不稳的：</font>weak and unsteady on the feet or in action</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She was feeling a bit groggy when I saw her. 当我看到她的时候她显得有些走路不稳。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]rickety, rocky,shaky, unbalanced, unsound, unstable, unsteady, wobbly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]balanced, stable, steady, sound  平衡的，稳定的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">无法思考的，头脑不清的：</font>not able to think or move normally because of being tired, sick, etc.</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I'm still a little groggy from my nap. 我还没完全从睡梦中清醒过来。‖The  medicine  sometimes  makespatients groggy. 这种药偶尔会让病人产生醉酒一样的麻醉感。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]dazed, dopey, muddleheaded, muzzy, punch-drunk, punchy, stupefied, zonked, zonked-out</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]clearheaded, unconfused 头脑清楚的</div>
<h2>acquisitive[sound:acquisitive.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">贪婪的：</font>strongly desirous of acquiring and possessing</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Acquisitive developers are trying to tear down the ancient temple and build a shopping mall instead. 贪婪的开发商打算铲平这座古老的神庙，取而代之地建造一座购物中心。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]avaricious, avid, coveting, covetous, grabby, grasping, mercenary, moneygrubbing, rapacious</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]benevolent, generous, liberal, philanthropic, munificent 慷慨的</div>
<h2>agonize[sound:agonize.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">折磨，使痛苦：</font>to cause to suffer agony</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She got into more trouble, further agonizing her poor mother. 她惹上了更多的麻烦，进一步加剧了她可怜的母亲所遭受的痛苦。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]bedevil, beset, besiege, curse, excruciate, harrow, persecute, plague, rack, torment, torture</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]comfort, console, solace, soothe 安抚，安慰</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vi. <font color="#aa00ff">感到痛苦：</font>to suffer agony, torture, or anguish</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She agonized for days over the moral issues involved.  一连几天她都为被卷入的道德纠纷而感到痛苦。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]anguish, bleed, hurt, mourn, sorrow, suffer</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]cheer, crow, delight, exult, joy, rejoice 感到高兴</div>
<h2>alienate[sound:alienate.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使…疏远：</font>to  make  unfriendly,  hostile,  or  indifferent  especially  where  attachment  formerlyexisted</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]His heartless treatment of their mother during the divorce proceeding has completely alienated the twochildren. 他在离婚过程中对妻子表现出来的残酷，已经彻底地让两个孩子与他疏远起来。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]alien, disaffect, disgruntle, sour</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]reconcile  使…重归于好</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">转让，让渡：</font>to convey or transfer (as property or a right) usually by a specific act rather than thedue course of law</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]A landowner has a right to alienate his right of ownership - in other words, he can sell the land if he wantsto.  地主拥有转让所有权的权力——也就是说如果愿意，他可以出售他的土地。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]assign, cede, convey, deed, make over</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]expropriate 接纳他人财产</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]unalienable adj. 不可予夺的，不可转让的</div>
<h2>anachronistic[sound:anachronistic.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">时代错误的：</font>chronologically misplaced</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Despite the occasional anachronistic word or concept, he has a good feel for the period. 尽管有时会犯一些词汇和概念上的时代性错误，但他对于那个时代的整体把握还是不错的。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]anachronic,anachronous</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]accurate 准确的</div>
<h2>antedate[sound:antedate.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">比…早，早于：</font>to be of an earlier date than</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The church antedates the village itself. 这座教堂甚至在村庄之前就存在了。‖Dinosaurs  antedatecavemen by millions of years. 恐龙比穴居人要早几百万年出现。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]antecede, forego, predate, preexist</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]follow, postdate, succeed 晚于</div>
<h2>arbitrary[sound:arbitrary.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">专横的，独断专行的：</font>having or showing a tendency to force one's will on others without anyregard to fairness or necessity</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]an arbitrary piano teacher who makes all her students do the same exercises over and over again 一个让学生反复练习同一首曲子的专横的老师</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]dictatorial, imperious, peremptory, willful</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">独裁的，拥有无限权力的：</font>exercising power or authority without interference by others</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a nation with no tradition of democracy, only a long history of arbitrary rulers 一个从来没有民主的传统，只有长期的独裁统治的国家</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]autocratic, czarist, despotic, monocratic, tyrannic, tyrannous</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]limited （权力）受限的；democratic 民主的；republican 共和的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">缺乏计划的，随意的：</font>lacking a definite plan, purpose, or pattern</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The order of the names of the 10 semifinalists is entirely arbitrary. 半决赛上十名上场选手的顺序完全是随机的。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]aimless, desultory, erratic, haphazard, scattered, slapdash, stray, willy-nilly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]methodical, orderly, organized, regular, systematic, systematized 有序的，有组织的</div>
<h2>bogus[sound:bogus.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">伪造的，假冒的：</font>being such in appearance only and made or manufactured with the intentionof committing fraud</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The evidence turned out to be completely bogus and the suspect may be innocent. 由于证据被发现是彻底伪造的，嫌犯很有可能是无辜的。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]counterfeit, fake, false, forged, inauthentic, phony , queer, sham, snide, spurious, unauthentic</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]authentic, genuine, real, unfaked, bona fide 真实的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">虚伪的，做作的：</font>lacking in natural or spontaneous quality</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]There was often a lot of bogus conviviality at the company’s parties.  公司的聚会上往往有着虚伪的欢乐。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]affected, assumed, contrived, factitious, feigned, plastic, pretended, pseudo, simulated, unnatural</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]artless, natural, spontaneous, unaffected, uncontrived, unfeigned, unforced 真诚的，不虚伪的</div>
<h2>brandish[sound:brandish.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">（带有威胁性地）挥舞：</font>to shake or wave (as a weapon) menacingly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I could see that the suspect was brandishing a knife and was in no way inclined to surrender. 我可以看到嫌犯在挥舞着一把刀，完全没有要投降的倾向。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]shake, swing, wave</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]drop  放下（武器等）</div>
<h2>cherished[sound:cherished.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">受喜爱的，珍爱的：</font>granted special treatment or attention</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a cherished heirloom that has been in the family for generations 在这个家族里流传了几代的为大家喜爱的纺织机‖He described the picture with his wife as his most cherished possession. 他把这张与妻子和合影看作是自己最为珍爱的财富。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]beloved, dear, favored, favorite, fond, loved, pet, precious, special, sweet</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]abhorred, abominated, despised, detested, disdained, disliked, execrated, hated, loathed 被厌恶的</div>
<h2>counterproductive[sound:counterproductive.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">反效果的，阻碍预期目标的：</font>not producing or tending to hinder the attainment of a desired goal</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Violence as a means to achieve an end is counterproductive. (W. E. Brock) 用暴力来实现目标往往是事与愿违的。——W. E.  布洛克‖His uncontrollable anger is very counterproductive to his attempt at saving hismarriage. 他无法自控的愤怒只会对他拯救婚姻的企图起反作用。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]feckless, hamstrung, ineffective, ineffectual, inefficacious, inefficient, inexpedient</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]effective, effectual, efficacious, efficient, expedient, operant  行之有效的</div>
<h2>deflect[sound:deflect.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使偏斜，使转向：</font>to turn aside especially from a straight course or fixed direction</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The goalie deflected the ball with his hands. 守门员用双手将球击出。‖They  are  trying  to  deflect  thepublic attention from the troubled economy. 他们试图将公众的注意力从经济的困境中移开。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]divert, redirect, swing, veer, wheel, whip</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]deflection n. 偏转，偏离</div>
<h2>erroneous[sound:erroneous.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">错误的，不正确的：</font>containing or characterized by error</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The news article about the new drug was filled with much erroneous information. 有关新药的新闻报道里充斥着大量的错误信息。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]inaccurate, incorrect, inexact, invalid, mistaken, unsound, untrue, untruthful, wrong</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]accurate, correct, errorless, exact, precise, right, sound, true, valid, veracious  正确的，准确的</div>
<h2>fanciful[sound:fanciful.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">幻想中的，不真实的：</font>not real and existing only in the imagination</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a fanciful tale of a monster in the woods 一个有关栖息在丛林中的怪兽的传说故事</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]chimerical, fabulous, fantastic, fictional, fictitious, ideal, invented, mythical, notional, phantom, visionary</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]actual, existent, existing, real 真实存在的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">不切实际的，荒谬的：</font>conceived or made without regard for reason or reality</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She harbors the fanciful notion that she has a talent for singing.  她怀着一个不切实际的空想：她有着歌唱家的天赋。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]absurd, bizarre, crazy, foolish, insane, nonsensical, preposterous, unreal, wild</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]realistic, reasonable 现实的，有理的</div>
<h2>fleeting[sound:fleeting.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">稍纵即逝的，短暂的：</font>lasting only for a short time; passing swiftly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]They have been waiting for more than 4 hours but caught only a fleeting glimpse of the movie star. 他们苦等了至少四个小时，却最终只短短地瞟到了电影明星一眼。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]brief, ephemeral, evanescent, flash, fugitive, impermanent, passing, temporary, transient, transitory</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]ceaseless, deathless, eternal, everlasting, immortal, lasting, permanent, perpetual, timeless 永恒的</div>
<h2>foreground[sound:foreground.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">强调，重视：</font>to indicate the importance of by centering attention on</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He repeatedly foregrounded his experience in international affairs  in the course of his campaign for thepresidency. 在他竞选总统的过程中，他一再强调自己在处理国际事务方面的经验。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accent, accentuate, emphasize, feature, highlight, illuminate, press, punctuate, stress</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]de-emphasize, understate, play down 轻描淡写</div>
<h2>gawky[sound:gawky.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">（举止）笨拙的：</font>having or showing an inability to move in a graceful manner</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The pathetic gawky woman was once a lithe ballerina but got severely injured in a car accident.  这个可怜的步态笨拙的妇女本来是一名轻巧优雅的芭蕾舞女，但是在一次车祸中受了重伤。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]awkward, clumsy, gawkish, graceless, uncoordinated, ungainly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]agile, graceful, lithe, nimble  灵巧的，敏捷的；elegant 优雅的</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]gawkiness n. 笨拙</div>
<h2>indecorous[sound:indecorous.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">不合乎礼节的，不得体的：</font>conflicting with accepted standards of good conduct or good taste</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]How can you make such an indecorous joke for a solemn moment in the marriage ceremony   你怎么能在庄严肃穆的结婚典礼上开那样一个不得体的玩笑呢？</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]amiss, graceless, improper, inapposite, infelicitous, malapropos, perverse, unbecoming, unfit, unseemly,unsuitable, wrong</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]appropriate, becoming, befitting, decorous, felicitous, fit, genteel, meet, proper, seemly, suitable  得体的，合乎礼节的</div>
<h2>lax[sound:lax.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">松弛的，不紧的，不严格的：</font>not tense, firm, or rigid</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]exercises to improve lax muscles 锻炼松弛的肌肉‖The guidelines for the essay contest were fairlylax, permitting a wide variety of topics. 本次作文大赛的要求相对比较宽松，允许写多种类型的主题。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]flabby, flaccid, insecure, loose, loosened, relaxed, slackened, unsecured</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]taut, tense, tight 紧固的，牢固的；hard, harsh, rigid, rigorous, severe, stern, strict 严格的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">懈怠的，漫不经心的：</font>failing to give proper care and attention</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The university has been lax about enforcing these rules. 学校对于这些规定的施行显得漫不经心。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]careless, derelict, disregardful, heedless, lazy, neglectful, neglecting, negligent, remiss, slack</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]attentive, careful, cautious, conscientious, heedful, mindful, vigilant, wary 注意的，留心的</div>
<h2>lionize[sound:lionize.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">追捧，把…捧为名人：</font>to look on or treat (a person) as a celebrity</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She was lionized everywhere after her novel won the Pulitzer Prize.  在她的小说获得普利策奖之后，她无论走到哪都受到追捧。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]aggrandize, canonize, deify, dignify, elevate, ennoble, enshrine, ensky, enthrone, glorify, magnify</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]abase, degrade, demean, humble, humiliate 贬低，瞧不起</div>
<h2>lurid[sound:lurid.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">恐怖的，令人反感的：</font>causing horror or revulsion</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]We quickly drove past the lurid scene of the crash. 我们迅速驶过了可怕的车祸现场。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]appalling, atrocious, dreadful, frightful, ghastly, gruesome, hideous, horrid, horrific, macabre, monstrous,nightmarish</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]agreeable, appealing, delicious, delightful, enjoyable, enticing, inviting, pleasant, satisfying  令人愉悦的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">面色苍白的，病态的：</font>wan and ghastly pale in appearance</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The doctor was alarmed by the patient's lurid complexion. 病人惨白的面色给医生敲响了警钟。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]ashen, ashy, blanched, cadaverous, doughy, livid, mealy, paled, pallid, pasty, peaked, wan</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]blooming, florid, flush, full-blooded, glowing, rosy, rubicund, ruddy, sanguine 红润的，健康的</div>
<h2>malignant[sound:malignant.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">恶毒的，邪恶的：</font>having or showing a desire to cause someone pain or suffering for the sheerenjoyment of it; disposed to do evil</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She has a malignant wish to  poison  everyone who was smarter, richer, or better-looking than she was.她有着一个恶毒的愿望，那就是毒死所有比她聪明、有钱或者是比她更漂亮的人。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]atrocious, brutal, cruel, despiteful, malevolent, malicious, malign, mean, nasty, spiteful, vicious, virulent</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]benevolent, benign, benignant 慈善的，和蔼的；merciful  仁慈的</div>
<h2>notoriety[sound:notoriety.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">（尤指因为丑闻而出名的）名人：</font>a person who is widely known and usually much talked about,especially for something bad; a notorious person</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a television show featuring notorieties from 20 years of scandals 以二十年来因各色丑闻而出名的名人为卖点的电视节目</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]figure, icon, luminary, megastar, name, notable, personage, standout, star, superstar</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]nobody, noncelebrity 不知名的人</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】n. <font color="#aa00ff">坏名声：</font>the quality or condition of being notorious; ill fame</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She gained notoriety when nude photographs of her appeared in a magazine. 她的裸照出现在杂志上让她声名远播。‖His comment about the President has given him a notoriety that he enjoys very much. 他对于总统的评论让他获得了很让他满意的名声。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]infamy, obloquy, odium, opprobrium</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]anonymity, oblivion, obscurity 不知名，默默无闻；celebrity, fame, renown, repute 好名声</div>
<h2>overshadow[sound:overshadow.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使变黯淡：</font>to make dark, dim, or indistinct</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Large trees overshadow the yard and darken the house for much of the day. 大树为院子遮挡了阳光，并使屋子里一天之中的大多数时候都很昏暗。‖Her mother's illness overshadowed her childhood. 她母亲的疾病让她的童年缺乏亮色。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]becloud, befog, blacken, blear, blur, darken, dim, fog, haze, mist, obscure, overcast, overcloud, shroud</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]brighten, illuminate, illumine, lighten 照明，照亮</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">（在重要性上）超越，超过：</font>to exceed in importance</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The forward’s outstanding performance should not overshadow the achievements of the rest of the team.其他队员的贡献不应该因前锋的精彩表现而被忽略。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]eclipse, outrank, outshine, outstrip, overbalance, overweigh</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]fall behind 落后</div>
<h2>pioneer[sound:pioneer.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">扩荒者，先驱者：</font>one of the first to settle in a territory</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]the hardships that the pioneers endured while taming the wilderness 在驯服自然的过程中扩荒者所受到的种种磨难‖a pioneer in aviation 航空业的先驱</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]colonist, colonizer, homesteader, settler</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]follower 跟随者</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">最初的，最早的：</font>coming before all others in time or order</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]the nation's pioneer institutions for the education of African-Americans 为了非裔美国人的教育而设立的第一批教育机构</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]earliest, foremost, headmost, inaugural, initial, leadoff, maiden, original, premier, virgin</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]final, last, latest, terminal, terminating, ultimate 最后的，终结的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">开创，创造：</font>to open up (an area) or prepare (a way)</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He single-handedly pioneered the university’s institute for medical research. 他单枪匹马创建了这所大学里的医学研究所。‖rockets that pioneered outer space  开创了外太空纪元的火箭</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]begin, constitute, establish, inaugurate, initiate, innovate, institute, introduce, launch, plant, set up</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]close, end, shut,terminate, phase out 终止，淘汰</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]pioneering adj. 先驱性的，先导性的</div>
<h2>pragmatic[sound:pragmatic.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">实用主义的，务实的：</font>a practical approach to problems and affairs</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Pragmatic men of power have had no time or inclination to deal withsocial morality.(K. B. Clark)  务实的当权者不会有时间或者意向去处理社会道德的问题。——K.  B.  克拉克‖a  pragmatic  man,  not  given  to  grand,visionary schemes 一个不迷恋花哨空想的计划，而更注重实际的人</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]down-to-earth, earthy, hardheaded, matter-of-fact, practical</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]fanciful, idealistic, impractical, unrealistic, utopian, visionary 幻想的，不务实的</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]pragmatism n. 实用主义，务实主义</div>
<h2>refreshing[sound:refreshing.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">令人心身振奋的，提神的：</font>having a renewing effect on the state of the body or mind</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]A glass of cold water is very refreshing on such a hot day. 大热天里的一杯冰水真是让人心旷神怡。‖Itis refreshing to hear some good news about him.  能听到他的好消息真是让人振奋。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]bracing, cordial, invigorating, rejuvenating, restorative, reviving, stimulating, stimulative, vitalizing</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]deadening, debilitating, draining, enervating, enfeebling, exhausting, sapping, wearying 令人虚弱的</div>
<h2>skittish[sound:skittish.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">容易受到惊吓的，胆小的：</font>easily frightened</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The kitty is skittish around people she doesn't know. 小猫看到不认识的人就会显得特别胆小害怕。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]fainthearted, fearful, fearsome, mousy, scary, timid, timorous, tremulous</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]adventuresome, adventurous, audacious, bold, daring, dashing, gutsy, venturesome, venturous  大胆的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">容易激动的：</font>easily excited by nature</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The skittish colt leapt up when we approached. 一看到我们靠近，小马驹就激动地猛跳起来。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]flighty, fluttery, hyper, hyperactive, hyperkinetic, jittery, jumpy, nervous, skittery, spasmodic, spooky</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]imperturbable, nerveless, unexcitable, unflappable, unshakable  不为所动的，沉着的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">善变的，多变的：</font>likely to change frequently, suddenly, or unexpectedly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The skittish housing market had both buyers and sellers on edge. 变幻莫测的房市让买家和卖家都坐立不安。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]capricious, changeful, flickery, fluctuating, fluid, inconstant, mercurial, mutable, temperamental, uncertain,unstable, unsteady, volatile</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]changeless, constant, immutable, invariable, settled, stable, stationary, steady, unvarying 不变的</div>
<h2>stigmatize[sound:stigmatize.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使蒙上污名：</font>to characterize or brand as disgraceful or ignominious</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Urban construction workers are often stigmatized by the rest of society as lazy and dirty. 城市里的建筑工人往往被社会里的其他人污蔑为是懒惰而肮脏的。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]abase, debase, degrade, demean, discredit, disgrace, dishonor, foul, humiliate, shame, sink, smirch</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]aggrandize, canonize, deify, elevate, exalt 提升（名誉，声望等）</div>
<h2>surpass[sound:surpass.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">超越，强于：</font>to become better, greater, or stronger than</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She always tried to surpass her older brother at anything he did, which results in his diffidence. 她在任何一个方面都要比她哥哥优秀，由此导致了他自信心的匮乏。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]beat, better, eclipse, exceed, excel, outclass, outmatch, outshine, outstrip, overtop, transcend</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]fall behind 落后</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">突破（界限，纪录等）：</font>to go beyond the limit of</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The sales of the band's newest CD have surpassed the combined sales of its last two albums. 乐队新专辑的发售量甚至超过了前两张销售量的总和。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]break, outreach, outrun, overpass, overreach, overrun, overstep</div>
<h2>thrill[sound:thrill.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">强烈的兴奋感，快感：</font>a pleasurably intense stimulation of the feelings</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Everyone gets a real thrill out of the Independence Day fireworks. 每个人都因独立日的焰火表演而感到无比的兴奋。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]bang, boot, exhilaration, frisson, jollies, kick, rush, titillation, wallop</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使兴奋，使激动：</font>a pleasurably intense stimulation of the feelings</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I was thrilled to hear that you got the promotion that you’d been so desperately wanting. 听到你终于获得了梦寐已久的升迁，我感到非常激动。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]arouse, charge, electrify, excite, exhilarate, galvanize, intoxicate, provoke, stimulate, titillate, pump up</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]bore, jade, pall, tire, weary 使厌倦</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]thrilling adj. 刺激的；thriller n. 恐怖电影</div>
<h2>timely[sound:timely.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">及时的，无拖延的：</font>done, carried out, or given without delay</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]When I order a pizza, I expect it to be delivered in a timely manner. 当我在外面点了披萨饼，我就希望它能按时送到。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]immediate, punctual, speedy</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]belated, late, tardy 迟到的，延迟的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">恰到好处的，合乎适宜的：</font>appropriate or adapted to the times or the occasion</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Timely invitation to lunch that came just as I was starting to feel hungry. 正当我开始感到饥饿的时候，就有人适时地邀请我吃午饭了。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]opportune, seasonable, well-timed</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]inopportune, unseasonable, untimely 不合时宜的</div>
<h2>trifling[sound:trifling.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">细微的，不重要的：</font>lacking in significance or solid worth</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Deciding what you want to do for a living is no trifling matter. 决定维持生计的行当可不是一件小事。‖trifling differences between the theatrical and DVD versions of the movie 影院版和DVD 版电影当中的细微区别</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]frivolous, inconsequential, inconsiderable, insignificant, minor, minute, negligible, nugatory, slight, trivial</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]consequential, eventful, important, meaningful, momentous, significant, substantial, weighty 重要的</div>
<h2>abreast[sound:abreast.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adv. <font color="#aa00ff">并排地：</font>beside one another with bodies in line</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a group of youths riding four abreast  四个一排骑着车的孩子们</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]alongside, side by side</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]aimlessly, desultorily, erratically, haphazardly, irregularly, randomly, willy-nilly 随意地</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">熟知的：</font>up to a particular standard or level especially of knowledge of recent developments</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]She tried to keep abreast of the latest fashion trends. 她总是尽可能地跟上时尚的潮流。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]acquainted, conversant, informed, knowledgeable, versed, well-informed</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]ignorant, unacquainted, unfamiliar, uninformed, unknowledgeable 无知的，不熟悉的</div>
<h2>absent[sound:absent.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">未出现的，缺乏的：</font>not present, attending or existing</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The city's usual stir of activity was conspicuously absent due to the report of an escaped lion from the zoo.一则动物园狮子逃跑的消息让这座城市缺少往日的繁华。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]away, lacking, missing, nonexistent, wanting</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]existent, present 存在的，出现的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">不专心的，走神的：</font>lost in thought</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]seemed absent because he nodded but didn’t say anything  他只点了点头但没说话，看起来像是走神了</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]abstracted, distracted, preoccupied</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]alert, vigilant, watchful, wary 警惕的；attentive, heedful, mindful  专注的</div>
<h2>acclaim[sound:acclaim.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">称赞：</font>public acknowledgment or admiration for an achievement</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Many people were involved in the search, but the person who actually found the missing girl got all theacclaim.  许许多多的人都参与了搜救行动，但是只有真正找到那个迷失的小女孩的人才受到称赞。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accolade, applause, credit, distinction, homage, honor, kudos, laud, laurels</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">赞扬，赞颂：</font>to declare enthusiastic approval of</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He was acclaimed as the country's greatest modern painter. 他被盛赞为国内最优秀的现代画家。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accredit, applaud, cheer, commend, endorse, exalt, hail, praise, salute, tout</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]castigate, excoriate, lambaste, pan, slam  猛烈抨击</div>
<h2>accomplish[sound:accomplish.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">完成，实现：</font>to carry through (as a process) to completion</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I don’t think we can accomplish our goal unless we cooperate. 我认为只有合作才能实现我们的目标。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]achieve, commit, execute, fulfill, make, perpetrate, prosecute, carry out</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]fail 失败</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]accomplishment n. 成就；accomplished adj. 有造诣的</div>
<h2>accord[sound:accord.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">一致：</font>a state of consistency</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]This map doesn't seem to be in accord with the current layout of the streets. 这幅地图似乎与当前的街道情况不尽一致。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accordance, agreement, conformity, congruence, congruity, consonance, harmony, tune</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]conflict, disagreement, incongruence, incongruity, incongruousness 不一致</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vi. <font color="#aa00ff">相符合，相一致：</font>to be consistent or in harmony</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a theory that accords with the known facts 与已知事实相一致的理论‖He claims that the newspaper’squote does not accord with what he actually said. 他声称报纸引用的他的话与原文并不相符。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]agree, chord, cohere, coincide, conform, correspond, fit, harmonize, jibe, sort, square, tally</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]differ, disagree 不相同，不一致</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">授予，给予：</font>to grant or give especially as appropriate, due, or earned</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Women were finally accorded the right to vote in 1920.  女性最终在1920 年获得了投票权。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accord, award, grant, vest, vouchsafe</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]withhold 保留，不给予；recant, retract, withdraw 撤回，收回</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]accordance n. 一致，和谐</div>
<h2>acknowledge[sound:acknowledge.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">承认：</font>to admit the existence, reality, or truth of</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He refused to acknowledge the fact that her daughter has gone. 他拒绝承认女儿已经死去的事实。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]admit, agree, allow, concede, confess, grant, own</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]deny  否认</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]acknowledgement n. 承认</div>
<h2>acquire[sound:acquire.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">获取，获得：</font>to get as one’s own</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]bacteria that acquire tolerance to antibiotics 产生了抗药性的细菌‖I  have  never  acquired  a  taste  forwine. 我从来就不具备对葡萄酒酒的品味能力。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]attain, capture, draw, gain, garner, get, make, obtain, procure, realize, reap, secure, win, bring in</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]forfeit, lose 丧失</div>
<h2>adversity[sound:adversity.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">厄运，逆境：</font>a state, condition, or instance of serious or continued difficulty or adverse fortune</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The fire is the test of gold, adversity of strong man.(Martha Graham)  烈火试真金，逆境炼勇士。—— 玛莎·葛兰姆‖finally overcame all the adversities of the Great Depression and rebuilt their fortunes 终于度过了大萧条的困境，开始重新创造他们的财富</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]ill, hardship, misadventure, mischance, mishap, tragedy</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]fortune, luck, serendipity 好运气</div>
<h2>affectation[sound:affectation.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">虚伪，做作：</font>the act of taking on or displaying an attitude or mode of behavior not natural to oneselfor not genuinely felt</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]the rolling of the ship made the young sailor squeamish 摇晃的船只让年轻的水手感到恶心</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]fa ade, guise, mannerism, pose, pretense, show</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]artlessness, genuineness, innocence, naivety  天真，淳朴</div>
<h2>affirm[sound:affirm.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">声称为真，肯定属实：</font>to assert (as a judgment or decree) as valid or confirmed</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He was unwilling to affirm without further study that the painting is an original Rembrandt. 在缺乏进一步研究的情况下，他不愿意声称这幅画作是出自伦布兰特的正品。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]allege, assert, aver, avouch, avow, contend, declare, insist, maintain, profess, protest, purport, warrant</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]deny, gainsay  否定，反对</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]affirmation n. 肯定，确认</div>
<h2>agility[sound:agility.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">（身手）敏捷：</font>ease and grace in physical activity</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]His agility on the parallel bars has won him several medals. 他在双杠上的矫捷身姿助他赢得了数枚奖牌。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]deftness, dexterity, nimbleness, sleight, spryness</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]awkwardness, clumsiness, gaucheness, gawkiness, gracelessness, ungainliness （行动）笨拙</div>
<h2>agreeable[sound:agreeable.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">令人愉悦的：</font>pleasing to the mind or senses especially as according well with one's tastes orneeds</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Would you mind putting on some agreeable music for dinner   你介意为晚饭放一些令人愉快的音乐吗？‖the agreeable melancholy resulting from a sense of the transitoriness of natural beauty 因为感慨自然之美稍纵即逝而产生的令人愉悦的忧伤</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]congenial,  delectable,  delicious,  delightful,  dulcet,  enjoyable,  felicitous,  gratifying,  heavenly,  palatable,pleasing, satisfying, savory</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]abhorrent, abominable, disagreeable, disgusting, loathsome, nauseating, repellent, repugnant, repulsive, revolting 令人厌恶的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">随和的：</font>having an easygoing and pleasing manner especially in social situations</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I have an agreeable art teacher who lets me do pretty much whatever I want.  我的艺术老师性格非常好，总是允许我去做我想做的事情。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]affable, genial, good-natured, good-tempered, gracious, mellow, nice, pleasant, sweet, well-disposed</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]choleric, dyspeptic, fussy, grouchy, irascible, irritable, peevish, touchy 脾气不好的，易怒的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">相一致的：</font>being in harmony</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]These new security measures are not agreeable with our core concepts of personal freedom. 这些新的安保措施和我们所信仰的人身自由彼此抵触。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]amicable, compatible, congenial, consistent, consonant, frictionless, kindred, unanimous, united</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]disagreeable, discordant, disunited, incompatible, inharmonious 不一致的</div>
<h2>alloy[sound:alloy.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">合金，混合物：</font>a distinct entity formed by the combining of two or more different things</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Brass is an alloy, consisting of copper and zinc. 黄铜是一种由铜和锌组成的合金。‖Television news hasalways been an alloy of journalism and show business. 电视新闻一直以来都是新闻界和演艺圈的混合体。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]admixture, amalgam, cocktail, composite, compound, fusion, intermixture, mix, mixture, synthesis</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]element （构成整体的）单个元素</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">掺杂，降低纯度：</font>to debase by the addition of an inferior element</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]idealism that was alloyed with political skill 因为掺入了政治技能而被削弱理想主义</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]adulterate, contaminate, dilute, extend, lace, pollute, sophisticate, thin</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]purify 纯化</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]unalloyed adj. 纯粹的，未掺杂的</div>
<h2>ambivalent[sound:ambivalent.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">（尤指感情、态度）矛盾的：</font>having a mixture of opposing feelings</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He maintained an ambivalent attitude to religion throughout his life. 他一生都对宗教抱有矛盾的心态。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]conflicting, contradictory, mixed</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]certain, decided, definite, positive, resolute, sure, unquestioning  明确的，毫无疑问的</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]ambivalence n. 矛盾心理</div>
<h2>analogous[sound:analogous.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">相似的，可比较的：</font>having qualities in common</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Bad-mouthing your sister is analogous to slapping her in the face - it's just as bad. 说你姐姐的坏话和当面扇她耳光是类似的——它们都是不好的行为。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]akin, cognate, comparable, connate, corresponding, matching, parallel, resembling, similar, suchlike</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]different, disparate, dissimilar, diverse, unlike  不同的，不相似的</div>
<h2>annotate[sound:annotate.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">做注解：</font>to furnish (a literary work) with critical commentary or explanatory notes</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The advent of e-books enables user to freely annotate what they are reading without worrying about beingfined by libraries.  电子书的出现使得用户可以在不用担心被图书馆处以罚金的情况下自由地在读物上作注。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]commentate, footnote, gloss</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]annotation n. 注解，注释</div>
<h2>antipathy[sound:antipathy.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">厌恶，反感：</font>settled aversion or dislike</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I feel no antipathy towards any of my opponents in the tournament. 我对锦标赛中碰到的任何对手都不存在反感。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]animosity, animus, antagonism, bitterness, enmity, gall, grudge, hostility, jaundice, rancor</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]amity 友好，和睦；liking, partiality, predilection, prepossession 偏爱，喜爱</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】n. <font color="#aa00ff">令人反感的事物：</font>an object of aversion</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Cruelty to animals is one of my most deeply felt antipathies. 虐待动物是最让我反感的行为之一。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]abhorrence, abomination, anathema, aversion, detestation, execration</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]beloved, darling, dear, love  令人喜爱的人或事物</div>
<h2>antiquated[sound:antiquated.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">古老的，过时的：</font>outmoded or discredited by reason of age: being out of style or fashion</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]We saw an antiquated hand-cranked rope-making machine at the textiles museum. 我们在纺织博物馆里看到了一台手摇式古董制绳机。‖antiquated methods of farming 已经过时的耕种技术</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]antique,  archaic,  dated,  fossilized,  moribund,  moth-eaten,  obsolete,  outdated,  outmoded,  outworn,prehistoric, rusty</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]contemporary, current, modern, recent 当前的，现代的</div>
<h2>antithetical[sound:antithetical.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">完全对立的，相反的：</font>being in direct and unequivocal opposition</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Spiritual ideals seem antithetical to the materialism embraced by modern society. 精神上的理想境界往往同当代社会所推崇的唯物主义相抵触。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]antipodal, antipodean, contradictory, contrary, diametric, opposite, polar</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]equivalent, identical, same 完全一致的，相等的</div>
<h2>apparition[sound:apparition.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">鬼魂，幽灵：</font>a ghostly figure</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]An eccentric claimed to have photographed an apparition in her very own house. 一个行为怪异的人声称在她的住所里拍到了一张幽灵的照片。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]ghost, phantasm, phantom, shade, shadow, specter, spirit, spook, sprite, vision, visitant, wraith</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]entity, substance 实体</div>
<h2>applicable[sound:applicable.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">可用的，可行的：</font>capable of being put to use or account</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Is that Act applicable in this case where suspect is a foreigner  那条法规适用于这个嫌犯不是本国公民的案件么？</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]actionable, applicative, applied, functional, practicable, serviceable, useful, workable</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]impractical, inapplicable, unusable, unworkable, useless 不可用的，不可行的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">相关的，有关的：</font>having to do with the matter at hand</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He rarely makes comment that is applicable to our discussion. 他的评论很少和我们讨论的题目搭边。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]apposite, apropos, germane, material, pointed, relative, relevant</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]extraneous, immaterial, impertinent, inapposite, irrelevant, pointless  无关的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">合适的，恰当的：</font>meeting the requirements of a purpose or situation</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He has been busy in selecting the most applicable word for his PhD thesis. 他一致忙于为自己的博士论文选择最为恰当词汇。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]appropriate, apt, becoming, befitting, felicitous, fitting, meet, pretty, proper, right, suitable</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]improper, inappropriate, inapt, incongruous, malapropos, misbecoming, unbecoming, unfitting, unmeet, unseemly, unsuitable, wrong 不恰当的</div>
<h2>apprehensive[sound:apprehensive.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">知晓的，理解的：</font>having specified facts or feelings actively impressed on the mind</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]I am fully apprehensive of the options, I assure you. 我向你保证这些观点我都理解了。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]alive, aware, cognizant, mindful, sensible, sentient, ware, witting</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]ignorant, insensible, oblivious, unaware, unconscious, unmindful, unwitting 不知晓的，无知觉的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">恐惧的，害怕的：</font>anxious or fearful about the future</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]People apparently haven’t recovered from the devastating terrorist attack and are still terribly apprehensiveabout the future. 人们显然没有从那场严重的恐怖袭击中恢复过来，对于未来仍然充满了恐惧。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]afraid, aghast, fearful, frightened, horrified, hysterical, scared, shocked, terrified</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]dauntless, fearless, intrepid, unafraid 无所畏惧的；confident 充满自信的</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]apprehension n. 理解；忧虑，恐惧</div>
<h2>arcane[sound:arcane.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">（语言）晦涩的，隐晦的：</font>having an often intentionally veiled or uncertain meaning</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The rebate form uses arcane language, the only purpose of which seems to be to disqualify buyers fromactually getting a rebate.  折扣单上的条文晦涩难懂，这样做的唯一目的也许就是让消费者不能真正地享受到折扣。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]ambiguous, dark, elliptical, equivocal, murky, mysterious, mystic, nebulous, occult, opaque</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]accessible, clear, obvious, plain, unambiguous, unequivocal 清晰明了的，明确的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">深奥的，难以理解的：</font>difficult for one of ordinary knowledge or intelligence to understand</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Grammatical rules seem extremely arcane to generations of students who were never taught grammar inthe first place. 对那些从未学习过语法的几代学生来说，语法规则犹如天书。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]abstruse, cryptic, deep, enigmatic, esoteric, hermetic, impenetrable, inscrutable, recondite, uncanny</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]easy, facile, shallow, simple, superficial 浅显易懂的</div>
<h2>argument[sound:argument.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">争吵，争论：</font>an often noisy or angry expression of differing opinions</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The couple’s arguments were often loud enough to be heard all over the neighborhood. 这对夫妻吵架的声音往往大到能被邻居听见。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]altercation, controversy, disagreement, dispute, hassle, imbroglio, quarrel, squabble, tiff, wrangle</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】n. <font color="#aa00ff">（逻辑上的）论证：</font>a coherent series of statements leading from a premise to a conclusion</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]In his argument the author committed several logical fallacies which undermined its soundness.  在作者的论述中出现了若干逻辑谬误，从而降低了它论证的力度。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]account, accounting, argumentation, case, explanation, rationale, reasoning</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】n. <font color="#aa00ff">观点，论点：</font>an idea or opinion that is put forth in a discussion or debate</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]It is and will always be my argument that we have too many problems here on earth to concern ourselves with manned trips to Mars. 我现在和以后的观点都将会是：在我们解决地球上的问题之前，不应该花太多的心思考虑载人火星计划的事情。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]assertion, point, position, stand, thesis</div>
<h2>array[sound:array.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">排列，阵列：</font>a regular and imposing grouping or arrangement</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]a marching band’s carefully choreographed array 前进中的乐队所摆出的经过复杂编排的方针</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]arrangement, disposal, disposition, distribution, ordering, sequence, setup</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]disorder, disorganization 混乱，无序</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">排列，摆放：</font>to arrange or display in or as if in an array</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]data arrayed in descending order 按照降序排列的数据‖arrayed  his  baseball  cards  in  order  of  theirrarity and consequent monetary value 把他的棒球卡按照稀有程度——也即价值排列</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]arrange, classify, codify, dispose, marshal, organize, range, systematize, draw up, lay out</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]derange, disarrange, disarray, disorder, mess, rumple, upset 弄乱，打乱</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">装饰，装修：</font>to dress or decorate especially in splendid or impressive attire</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He had already arrayed himself in his best clothes. 他已经穿上了他最好的服装。‖a  door  arrayed  for  theholidays with a beautiful evergreen wreath 被美丽的常青花环妆点的节日大门</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]adorn, beautify, bedeck, bedizen, blazon, embellish, emblaze, emboss, enrich, garnish, ornament, trim</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]blemish, deface, disfigure, mar, scar, spoil 破坏，损毁</div>
<h2>assail[sound:assail.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">抨击，严厉批评：</font>to criticize harshly and usually publicly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The union organizers assailed the chemical company for failing to provide a safe working environment.工会主席因为这家化工企业不能为员工提供安全的生产环境而对其进行了严厉的抨击。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]abuse, bash, belabor, blast, castigate, excoriate, lambaste, savage, scathe, slam, trash, vituperate</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]acclaim, commend, compliment, hail, laud, praise  表扬，称赞</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">攻击，猛攻：</font>to take sudden, violent action against</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He was assailed by a young man with a knife. 他被一个持刀的年轻人揍了一顿。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]assault, attack, beset, charge, raid, rush, storm, strike, set on</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]defend, guard, protect, shield 防御，守卫</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]assailable adj. 易受攻击的</div>
<h2>attest[sound:attest.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">证实，为…作证：</font>to give evidence or testimony to the truth or factualness of</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]Her fine work attests her ability.  她的优秀作品能够证明她的能力。‖I can attest that she was at the party.我可以为她当时在聚会上作证。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]argue, authenticate, certify, corroborate, substantiate, support, testify, validate, verify, vindicate</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]contradict, disprove, gainsay, rebut, refute 反驳，否定</div>
<h2>attune[sound:attune.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使协调，使和谐：</font>to bring into harmony</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]After years spent in academia, he found it difficult to attune himself to the corporate culture. 在学术圈摸爬滚打多年之后，他发现自己很难融入企业文化之中。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]accommodate, conciliate, conform, coordinate, key, reconcile</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]disharmonize  使不和谐；disarray, disorder, disorganize, disrupt 弄乱，打乱</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]attunement n. 调音，协调</div>
<h2>auspicious[sound:auspicious.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">好兆头的：</font>pointing toward a happy outcome</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]began the season with an auspicious win against their strongest football rival  在赛季之初就战胜了最强的对手，为整个赛季赢得了好兆头</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]bright, encouraging, golden, heartening, hopeful, promising, propitious</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]baleful,  dark,  direful,  doomy,  foreboding,  gloomy,  menacing,  minatory,  ominous,  portentous,  sinister, threatening 不详的，凶兆的</div>
<h2>austere[sound:austere.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">朴素的，朴实无华：</font>markedly simple or unadorned</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]For the private office of the CEO of the large corporation, the room is unexpectedly austere. 出人意料的是，大公司总裁的私人办公室居然十分朴素。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]plain, spartan, stark, unadorned</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]deluxe, lavish, luxurious, plush, sumptuous 奢华的；elaborate, fancy 花哨的</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">严肃的，令人生畏的：</font>stern and cold in appearance or manner</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]an austere fortress at the top of some formidable cliffs 建立在悬崖峭壁之上的一座令人畏惧的堡垒‖In his memory his deceased grandfather is an austere, distant, cold person. 在他的记忆之中，已过世的祖父是一个严肃、冷漠而难以接近的人。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]dour, fierce, flinty, forbidding, formidable, gruff, intimidating, lowering, rough, rugged, severe, steely</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]benign, benignant, gentle, mild, tender 和蔼的，温柔的</div>
<h2>bash[sound:bash.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n. <font color="#aa00ff">猛击：</font>a forceful blow</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He has not been the same ever since he received that bash on his head. 自从他脑袋被别人打了之后，他就变得大不一样。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]bang, bat, beat, crack, hit, knock, lash, poke, pound, punch, slam, slap, smash, spank, stroke, swat</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">攻击，用力击打：</font>to strike violently and often repeatedly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The angry child kept bashing her toy with a hammer until it broke. 愤怒的小孩用锤子不断地敲击她的玩具，直到它彻底被破坏。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]baste, batter, buffet, hammer, lace, maul, nail, smash, strike</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法3】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">抨击，严厉批评：</font>to criticize harshly and usually publicly</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]In all of talk radio no other host seems to enjoy bashing liberals as much as he does. 在电台节目再没有像他一样热衷于抨击自由主义者的主持人了。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]abuse, assail, belabor, blast, castigate, excoriate, lambaste, savage, scathe, slam, trash, vituperate</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]acclaim, commend, compliment, hail, laud, praise  表扬，称赞</div>
<h2>bask[sound:bask.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vi. <font color="#aa00ff">休息，悠然自得：</font>to lie or relax in a pleasant warmth or atmosphere</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]We blissfully basked at the seashore over the long holiday. 我们在海滩上躺着晒太阳，享受着漫长的假期。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]loll, lounge, relax, repose</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]drudge, grind, hustle, labor, moil, plod, slave, sweat, toil, travail, work  （辛苦地）干活，工作</div>
<h2>belligerent[sound:belligerent.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】adj. <font color="#aa00ff">好斗的，好战的：</font>inclined to or exhibiting assertiveness, hostility, or combativeness</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The coach became quite belligerent and spit at an umpire after being thrown out of the game. 教练变得好斗起来，以至于在被罚出场外之后转身向裁判吐口水。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]aggressive,  agonistic,  assaultive,  bellicose,  combative,  contentious,  disputatious,  feisty,  gladiatorial,militant, pugnacious, quarrelsome, truculent, warlike</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]dove, pacific, peaceful  爱好和平的</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[派]belligerence n. 好战，好斗</div>
<h2>beset[sound:beset.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">使苦恼，骚扰：</font>to cause persistent suffering to</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]He has been beset by a lack of self-confidence virtually his entire life. 事实上他的一生都在被缺乏自信所困扰。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]agonize, anguish, bedevil, besiege, curse, excruciate, harrow, persecute, plague, rack, torment, torture</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]comfort, console, solace, soothe 安抚，安慰</div><div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法2】vt. <font color="#aa00ff">攻击，袭击：</font>to set upon</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]The settlers were beset by savages.  定居者们遭到了野蛮人的袭击。‖The  unsuspecting  tourists  weresuddenly beset by robbers. 丝毫没有准备的游客遭到了歹徒的突然袭击。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]assail, assault, attack, charge, raid, rush, storm, strike, set on</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[反]defend, guard, protect, shield 防御，守卫</div>
<h2>blackmail[sound:blackmail.mp3]</h2>	<div style="font-size:20px;text-align:left">【考法1】n./vi. 敲诈，勒索：extortion of money  or something else of value from a person by the threat ofexposing a criminal act or discreditable information</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[例]It looks like these pornographic pictures were being used for blackmail. 看起来有人用这些不雅照进行敲诈勒索。</div><div style="text-indent:3em;font-size:15px;text-align:left">[近]extortion</div>
